isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 2000, 4000, 8000 - BATTERY, CHARGING AND CRANKING SYSTEMS - DESCRIPTION - Cranking Motor System And Circuits

svcprocinfo.para: The cranking motor provides the rotation of the engine crankshaft, through the flywheel, that is needed to start the engine.
The cranking motor circuits provide power to the cranking motor to turn over the crankshaft of the engine. If all other systems are operational, the engine will start.
Components of the system without International engines consist of the crank motor and solenoid, the key start switch (or push button), and a magnetic switch.

Components of the system with International engines consist of the crank motor and solenoid, the key start switch (Or push button), crank inhibit relay, start relay, the Electronic Control Module (ECM), and a clutch switch with a manual transmission, or a neutral position switch with an automatic transmission.

svcsubproc.title: Cranking Motor Thermal Overcrank Protection

note.para: Cranking motors ending in a type 50, like 350 or 450, contain thermal overcrank protection.

svcsubproc.para: On vehicles with thermal overcrank protection, excessive cranking will cause cranking motor temperature to reach a pre-set thermal overcrank limit., The thermal switch will then open causing the motor to disengage. When the crank motor cools, the switch closes, permitting the crank motor to operate again. The thermal switch interrupts the current to the cranking system mag switch, or the start relay with International electronic engines.
